ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to conduct research through an experiment and stretch one question into 70 pages of writing and thinking

i learned how to do original research beginning with finding a topic, formulating research questions, conducting a literature review to find gaps or further directions, selecting data and methodology to best understand a topic and answer research questions, analyzing the data and finally presenting solutions and further directions
This class offered helpful thesis support.
I gained feedback and guidance on writing the senior thesis for sociology, as well as helpful progress checks and assignments to distribute the work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths - goal setting 
weakness - time management

my advisor provided feedback and answered questions whenever i asked but at times it felt like feedback was harder to come by from the instructor for the course. the teaching fellow was always available and provided feedback/answered questions whenever I reached out. Specifically I think there could be more scaffolding for assignments (in terms of both deadlines and details to be included) and also I think the classes themselves need to have more planning/an agenda than just updating with where we are and what challenges were running into. Possibly workshop 2-3 peoples thesis once a week? The people select which week?
Strengths - encouraging atmosphere, flexibility, support/feedback whenever you need it; weaknesses - intensity of experience depends on your advisor (but that is all theses)!
Professor Erikson is great! Its great being able to develop such a close relationship with the DUS through this colloquium.

I think that the most helpful parts of the course were the checkpoints provided by the different assignments given over the course of the semester and the faculty and peer reviews of work. A large portion of class time, however, tended to be spent giving individual progress updates on work being done. I think these check-ins were less helpful than more hands-on workshopping of different aspects of the research process would have been, or additional peer/faculty reviews of completed work. I think the class would also benefit from more engagement with other members of the sociology faculty, who could cycle through to give presentations or feedback on different aspects of research. Finally, I think the outlining of checkpoints for work over the course of the semester could be made more explicit and detailed in its expectations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes year long is better than semester thesis
yes. but do the work as its planned. conducting original research/writing a full thesis will be really satisfactory at the end
If you're excited about conducting original research, yes! Otherwise, might be worth it to do the non-intensive.
Yes, its required for the major

For sociology majors deciding whether or not to pursue the intensive track, I would definitely highlight the intellectual excitement and fulfillment of pursuing independent sociological research on a topic of your choosing. For those with the passion and dedication, I would absolutely recommend the yearlong thesis.
